sub_title: Working on research and business opportunities to accelerate the energy transition.
summary:
People describe me as a socially capable nerd. I am passionate about science in general, but physics and chemistry have my heart in particular. During my PhD research, I reveled in materials science and in studying the nitty-gritty details of nanotechnology. However, sometimes I missed discussions about the bigger picture, the ‘what is it all good for?’. In addition, I had quite an opinion about the way that doing science was organized at the universities.

That is why I joined the central works council of the Foundation FOM – the funder of my research. This choice defined my further career. I learned that there was a whole world out there in which organizational challenges, policymaking and scientific content were close connected. Best of all was the fact that you could actually make a difference. 

When I joined FOM (later absorbed in NWO) as programme officer, I was quickly emerged further into this world. I got to know the fantastic Dutch physics community quite well, and even got to play a nice role in it. It was a very instructive time in which I learned a lot about the interface between science and politics. I coordinated scientific programmes, organised funding opportunities, lobbied at the government for more investments in academic research and worked on several large national initiatives. 

Lately I was asked to embark on a new challenge. To set up a new research institute on energy storage and conversion at Eindhoven University of Technology. An institute in which all relevant faculties of the university and the closely linked DIFFER institute can participate. At the same time I will start as general secretary of the Netherlands Energy Research Alliance (NERA). A new role in which organizational, political and scientific challenges come together in order to work on one of the most important questions of our time? Of course I said ‘yes’!

profile_positions.description: In EIRES we bring together excellent research and innovative business opportunities for the energy transition. EIRES consists of researchers from the TU/e departments applied physics, built environment, chemistry & chemical engineering, electrical engineering, industrial engineering & innovation sciences, and mechanical engineering. In multidisciplinary teams we work together with knowledge (DIFFER, TNO) as well as business (Nouryon, VDL) partners to accelerate the energy transition. For more information see www.tue.nl/eires

profile_positions.description:
NERA aims for optimal knowledge sharing, coordination and cooperation in the Dutch energy research for an effective and successful energy transition. NERA represents the Dutch energy research internationally by participating in the ExCo Board of the European Energy Research Alliance (EERA) and by participating in trade missions.
As general secretary I am responsible for the day to day operations of the NERA and the preparation of the meetings of the Board and Scientific Board.

profile_positions.description:
Organising and coordinating physics research at Stichting FOM (Foundation for Fundamental Research on Matter), actively involved in the transition from FOM to NWO and the formation of the new NWO Institute organisation.
Developing and executing research policy: coordinator for the policy w.r.t. the FOM Institutes, programme manager for FOM-institute DIFFER, responsible for the theoretical high energy physics community, secretary of the Platform Universitaire Natuurkunde (PUN), and of the Raad voor de Natuur- en Scheikunde.

profile_positions.description:
Academic researcher on a FOM proposal at the Condensed Matter and Interfaces group of the Debye Institute for Nanomaterials Sciences. 
Focus of the research is on the use of scanning probe microscopy (STM/AFM) to study the fundamental properties of functional nanoparticles and their assemblies. This ranges from graphene flakes to nanocrystal assemblies.
